Description: Rim and body fragment of deep ledge rimmed bowl with slightly offset rim. Faience of bright turquoise blue. May belong with Eg.Inv. 3577. 10, though rim is irregular, or comes from another vessel of similar shape.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar rim forms have been produced in Egypt since the Late Period, see for example 4th and 3rd to 1st century BC parallels (Nenna 2013, Fig. 6.4, T6.4). However, the paste and glaze is distinctly Roman, commonly dated 1st to 2nd century AD as on similar ledge rim bowls (Nenna 2013, T12.5 variant). Similar, but rare variants of this form have been found within late 1st to early 3rd century AD contexts at Mons Claudianus, probably produced in Memphis (Tomber 2006, types 4 to 10; Petrie 1909). Close parallels from workshop in Elephantine, Early Roman in date, and based on Italian Roman Red slipped tableware forms (Rodziewicz 2005, 28, pl. 12, no. 215). From Naukratis, excavated in 1885 by William Matthew Flinders Petrie for the Egypt Exploration Fund, assigned to the EEF by the Egyptian government; October 28, 1885: voted to the MFA at EEF general meeting; sent over February 1886. (Accession date: 1886). Found with faience objects given by the EEF: Eg.Inv.3577 to Eg.Inv.3595 and 02.770, 72.1418, and 88.1003, P.725 to P.824, P.4418 to P.8145. Nenna, M.-D. 2013. Faience vessels and objects in Nicholson, P. T. (ed.) Working in Memphis: The production of faience at Roman period Kom Helul. London: Egypt Exploration Society: 106-132. Nenna, M.-D. and M. Seif el-Din. La vaisselle en faïece d’époque gréco- romaine. Études Alexandrines 4. Cairo: IFAO. Tomber, R. 2006. The pottery, in V.A.Maxfield and D.P.S. Peacock (eds) Survey and excavation at Mons Claudianus 1987-1993. Vol.3 Ceramic vessels and related objects. IFAO Cairo. 3-238.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (FC.39)
